channel.title: WSJ.com: Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: Thai Central Bank Can Cut More, But Not Much Room Left, Says Deputy Governor
item.description: The Thai central bank stands ready to cut rates further, but that alone won’t fix the country’s economic woes, said Piti Disyatat, deputy governor for monetary stability at the Bank of Thailand in an interview.
item.dc:creator: Fabiana Negrin Ochoa

item.title: The Bureau of Labor Statistics will bring some furloughed employees back to work so it can publish the September consumer-price index, a key inflation report, an administration official said
item.description: The Bureau of Labor Statistics will bring some furloughed employees back to work so it can publish the September consumer-price index, a key inflation report, an administration official said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Kiernan

item.title: Fed’s Barr Urges Caution With Further Rate Moves, Underscoring Committee’s Divisions
item.description: After the Federal Reserve’s initial rate cut last month, the central bank should proceed carefully with further adjustments to its policy stance, Fed governor Michael Barr said, citing concerns that prices are still rising too quickly.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: The books have closed on the U.S. government’s fiscal 2025. Here’s what has changed about the federal budget—and what hasn’t.
item.description: The books have closed on the U.S. government’s fiscal 2025. Here’s what has changed about the federal budget—and what hasn’t.
item.dc:creator: Anthony DeBarros

item.title: German Exports Unexpectedly Fell in August as Uncertainty Weighed
item.description: Exports of goods fell 0.5% on month, hampered by weaker trade with other European nations and the uncertainty prompted by U.S. tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: China introduced new controls on rare-earth exports on Thursday, requiring foreign entities to obtain government approval before re-exporting products of Chinese origin to other countries
item.description: Beijing tightened its control over sectors crucial to making high-tech products including electric vehicles and jet fighters, threatening to reignite trade tensions with the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Miao

item.title: Philippine Central Bank Surprises With Rate Cut as Economy Slows
item.description: Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas delivered a fourth straight rate cut, surprising markets as it flagged a weaker growth outlook.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Lee

item.title: BOE Must Keep Key Rate Restrictive to Boost Growth, Mann Says
item.description: The Bank of England should keep its key rate high so as to foster conditions for future growth, rate-setter Catherine L. Mann said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Federal Reserve officials were divided over how much farther they should lower interest rates when they approved their first reduction of the year last month
item.description: The government shutdown has paused the economic data releases that could help resolve debates over how to manage thorny trade-offs.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: In Japan, as in the U.S., a new leader wants the central bank to make government debt more bearable, which could feed inflation, writes WSJ’s Greg Ip
item.description: In Japan, as in the U.S., a new leader wants the central bank to make government debt more bearable, which could feed inflation.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ip

item.title: IMF Chief Sees Global Growth Slowing ‘Only Slightly’ in Face of Higher Tariffs
item.description: The global economy is holding up better than expected in the face of higher tariffs and greater uncertainty about relations between powerful countries and the implications of technological change, the head of the International Monetary Fund said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Thai Central Bank Surprises Markets With Rate Hold
item.description: The Bank of Thailand’s monetary policy committee voted five to two to keep the policy rate at 1.50%, hitting the pause button again after delivering three cuts this year.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Lee

item.title: Heard on the Street: A small drop in mortgage rates in recent weeks triggered an outsize response from borrowers
item.description: A small drop in rates in recent weeks has triggered an outsize response from borrowers.
item.dc:creator: Carol Ryan

item.title: A host of alternative jobs data from Wall Street are pointing in the same direction: The U.S. labor market is losing steam
item.description: In a federal data blackout, Wall Street numbers and surveys are filling the void, and the nongovernment numbers are telling the same basic story: Few companies are hiring.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Putzier

item.title: German Industrial Production Slumps on Entrenched Tariff Uncertainty
item.description: Output in factories in Europe’s largest economy sank 4.3% on month, a considerably weaker result than consensus expectations.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Without China as a customer, American soybean farmers are in panic mode as they harvest what is expected to be a bumper crop
item.description: China hasn’t booked any U.S. soybean purchases in months. Farmers warn of a “bloodbath.”
item.dc:creator: Patrick Thomas

item.title: Canada Goods-Trade Deficit Widens as Exports Retreat
item.description: The country recorded a merchandise-trade shortfall of about $4.53 billion in August.
item.dc:creator: Robb M. Stewart

item.title: EU Plans 50% Tariff on Excess Steel Imports in Bid to Tackle Overcapacity
item.description: Growing overcapacity, rising steel imports and tariffs from other countries were compounding challenges for the EU steel sector, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Mauro Orru

item.title: Global Trade Growth to Be Stronger Than Expected, WTO Says
item.description: Global trade in goods will increase more rapidly than previously expected this year as purchases of goods related to artificial intelligence surge and a buildup in inventories in the U.S. softens the impact of higher tariffs, the World Trade Organization said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Federal-Worker Buyouts Are Kicking In, Darkening the U.S. Employment Picture
item.description: About 100,000 federal workers came off the payroll last week, adding strain to an already weakening labor market.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Louise Ensign

item.title: Unboxing the thrill of Labubus, or why so many young consumers are spending big on blind boxes
item.description: Getting hold of Labubus and other blind-box toys is a game of odds; the thrill of the surprise keeps young consumers coming back for more.
item.dc:creator: Audrey Valbuena

item.title: The monthly jobs numbers from the Bureau of Labor Statistics won’t arrive on time because of the government shutdown. But private firms are helping fill the gap.
item.description: The monthly government jobs numbers didn’t arrive on time. But private firms are helping fill the gap.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Putzier

item.title: The U.S. shed 32,000 private-sector jobs in September, payroll processing giant ADP said
item.description: The ADP private-sector jobs report showed a labor force that continues to deteriorate.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Putzier

item.title: Eurozone Inflation Picks Up Pace as ECB Looks Set to Keep Rates on Hold
item.description: European Central Bank rate setters are sanguine about potential pressures on prices and expect last month’s rise in inflation to be short-lived.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: BOE Deputy Governor Sees Inflation Resuming Fall After ‘Hump’
item.description: The recent pickup in inflation, which is projected to hit 4% this month before declining, is unlikely to have long-lasting consequences, said Sarah Breeden.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: U.S. Labor-Turnover Was Steady in August
item.description: The rate of layoffs in the economy was mostly steady at 1.1% from July. Hiring was largely steady as well, with the rate of new job offers holding at 3.2%.
item.dc:creator: Paulo Trevisani

item.title: ECB’s Lagarde Says Inflation Risks Are ‘Contained’
item.description: Eurozone inflation is unlikely to rise much above, or fall much below, the European Central Bank’s target despite a reshaping of global trade, President Christine Lagarde said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: U.S. Home Prices Continued to Cool Ahead of Fed’s Rate Cut
item.description: The S&P Cotality Case-Shiller National Home Price Index, which measures home prices across the country, rose 1.7% in the 12 months through July, down from 1.9% on year in June and continuing a run of the weakest price rises since July 2023.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: Heard on the Street: Problems in the for-sale housing market are starting to infect the rental business
item.description: Problems in the for-sale housing market are starting to infect the rental business.
item.dc:creator: Carol Ryan

item.title: BOE Has Scope for Careful and Gradual Rate Cuts, Says Ramsden
item.description: The Bank of England can continue to lower its key interest rate while bringing inflation down to its 2% target, deputy governor Dave Ramsden said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Sales of existing homes dipped in August, after high prices kept sales in check
item.description: The median home price rose to $422,600, up 2% from a year ago and the highest price ever for the month of August.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: Heard on the Street: With the Fed in cutting mode, many people expect mortgage rates to fall fast. Unfortunately, it isn’t that simple.
item.description: While the Federal Reserve has begun cutting rates again, there are many other factors that affect the cost of home loans.
item.dc:creator: Telis Demos

item.title: Census Bureau data show that average U.S. households haven’t gained ground economically since the Covid-19 pandemic struck
item.description: High-income households fared better than others, while women lost ground to men, according to Census Bureau data.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Putzier

item.title: Households earning between $50,000 and $100,000 are trading down, cutting back and feeling increasingly strapped, while high earners keep on spending
item.description: Households earning between $50,000 and $100,000 are trading down, cutting back and feeling increasingly strapped, while high earners keep on spending.
item.dc:creator: Alison Sider

item.title: German Consumers Feel Ever Gloomier as Economy Slumps
item.description: Concerns around unemployment drove the cautious mood among German shoppers.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: U.K. Consumers Sunnier as BOE Cuts Rates But Economic Fears Remain
item.description: U.K. consumers felt a little better about their finances this month as the Bank of England lowered borrowing costs, though sentiment remains weak amid wider economic turmoil.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby
